Package jnet

Class JClientSocket

java.lang.Object
jnet.JClientSocket
public class JClientSocket extends Object
C-style socket wrapper for clients.

  • Constructor Details

    • JClientSocket

      public JClientSocket()
      Constructs an uninitialized JClientSocket object. The internal Socket representation will only be initialized upon the call to JClientSocket::connect().
      See Also:
      • connect(java.lang.String,int)

    • JClientSocket

      public JClientSocket(Socket clientSocket)
      Constructs a partially initialized JClientSocket object. The JClientSocket::connect() method must still be called to fully initialize this object, but the optional argument allows for a pre-defined connection to be used instead.
      Parameters:
      clientSocket - a java Socket object used to begin the initialization of a JClientSocketet object.
      See Also:
      • connect(java.lang.String,int)

  • Method Details

    • getInputStream

      public InputStream getInputStream()
      Returns the InputStream object from the locally stored java Socket object. This is provided so servers can "listen" and "send" on the client socket. This function, unlike the C methods, is done in java through the I/O streams, which needs to be taken from the client socket for the listen/send calls.
      Returns:
      an InputStream object connected to the internal Socket object.

    • getOutputStream

      public OutputStream getOutputStream()
      Returns the OutputStream object from the locally stored java Socket object.
      Returns:
      an OutputStream object connected to the internal Socket object.
      See Also:
      • getInputStream()

    • connect

      public void connect(String ip, int port) throws IOException
      Connects this socket to a destination address. Performs the action of the C socket connect() by wrapping the creation of the java I/O streams. If the connection fails, an error is logged.
      Parameters:
      ip - an IP address to connect to.
      port - a port to connect to.
      Throws:
      IOException - if the java Socket object cannot be initialized.
      See Also:
      • Log

    • send

      public int send(byte[] payload)
      Sends a payload across the socket. This method integrates CRC and header options on its own. These elements should not be added by the caller (if they are, they will be ignored and treated as part of the message payload). The payload must contain at least 1 byte. If an error occurs with the CRC generation, header generation, payload structure, or send operation, a corresponding error will be logged and -1 returned.
      Parameters:
      payload - a byte array to send.
      Returns:
      the number of bytes sent, including the length of the attached crc, header, and possible pad bytes.
      See Also:
      • Log
      • CRC
      • Header

    • send

      public int send(String payload)
      Sends a string across the socket. Identical to JClientSocket::send(Bytes.stringToBytes(payload)).
      Parameters:
      payload - a string to send
      Returns:
      the number of bytes sent, including the length of the attached crc, header, and possible pad bytes.
      See Also:
      • send(byte[])

    • recv

      public byte[] recv()
      Receives bytes across the socket. If the read could not be performed or either the header or crc check fails, null is returned an an error is logged. This method validates and detaches the crc and header bytes if valid.

      When reading, Header.SIZE bytes are first read and parsed as a Header.Info object. If the header CRC check passes, Header.Info::size bytes are read. If the CRC check passes for this body, the payload is returned.

      Returns:
      the received bytes.
      See Also:
      • Log

    • srecv

      public String srecv()
      Receives bytes across the socket and parses them as a string. Identical to Bytes.bytesToString(JClientSocket::recv()). This implies null may be returned if the bytes cannot be parsed as a string for any reason.
      Returns:
      a string representation of the bytes read.
      See Also:
      • recv()

    • close

      public void close()
      Closes the socket connection. If the connection cannot be closed, an error is logged.
      See Also:
      • Log
